conclusion: To determine the change in average kinetic energy, analyze the Stirling cycle and ideal gas properties.
The Stirling cycle consists of four processes: A→B isothermal expansion, B→C adiabatic compression, C→D isothermal compression, D→A adiabatic expansion.
A→B is an isothermal process with constant temperature, pressure decreases as volume increases.
B→C is an adiabatic process with no heat exchange, temperature changes as volume changes.
C→D is an isothermal process with constant temperature, pressure increases as volume decreases.
D→A is an adiabatic process with no heat exchange, temperature changes as volume changes.
Since A→B and C→D are isothermal, temperatures at points A and D are the same.
Average kinetic energy of gas molecules in an ideal gas is directly proportional to temperature.
Since temperature at point D is the same as at point A, average kinetic energy remains unchanged.
Average kinetic energy does not change when transitioning from state D to state A.
